description: Tools recommended by The BBC News Labs

tools.name: Elasticsearch
tools.jt_why: It's flexible and fast, stores data in JSON format (good for data vis) with powerful query capabilities. It also has great aggregation functionality, useful for analytics. We built the Juicer (http://bbcnewslabs.co.uk/projects/juicer/index.html) on Elasticsearch

tools.name: ArchieML
tools.jt_what: A way of structuring text without giving up human readability
tools.jt_why: It lets technical and non-technical colleagues contribute and edit content, quickly, without requiring a massive content management system.

tools.name: Jekyll
tools.jt_what: A simple static site generator - we use it for bbcnewslabs.co.uk.
tools.jt_why: It lets everyone on the team manage the website just by editing markdown files on github. Very simple.

tools.name: R
tools.jt_what: A powerful statistics and data visualisation language and environment
tools.jt_why: R is the industry standard for quickly and powerfully exploring datasets.

tools.name: D3
tools.jt_what: Javascript library for displaying data on the web
tools.jt_why: D3 supports a huge variety of chart types, so once you learn how to use it you can visualise most datasets.

tools.name: Annotator (http://annotatorjs.org/)
tools.jt_what: Annotate text, videos, images with this javascript library
tools.jt_why: Lets you start adding metadata quickly to any webpage, with a plugin architecture for extensibility

tools.name: Chart.js (http://www.chartjs.org/)
tools.jt_what: Javascript library for HTML5 responsive charts
tools.jt_why: Lets you quickly create good-looking, animated and responsive chart

tools.name: Polymaps http://polymaps.org
tools.jt_what: An SVG map library, that allows you to mix SVG maps and image tiles

tools.name: Font Awesome
tools.jt_what: A library of icons expressed in CSS
tools.jt_why: It's easy and compatible with CSS frameworks like Twitter's Bootstrap
